intro: Acalypha deppeana, commonly known as the redleaf or red-leaf plant, is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of South America. It is characterized by its striking, colorful bracts that range from red to orange, which are often mistaken for flowers. The plant has palmate leaves with a velvety texture and a distinctive reddish or purplish hue. It thrives in warm, humid environments and is often cultivated as an ornamental plant. Acalypha deppeana is part of the Euphorbiaceae family, known for its diverse and often showy floral structures.

It is commonly found in lowland areas, often near rivers and in moist, shaded environments. This species thrives in humid climates with well-drained soil, making it a characteristic plant of tropical rainforests. It is also occasionally found in parts of the Pacific Islands. Despite its aesthetic appeal, it has since become invasive in some areas, outcompeting native vegetation and altering local ecosystems.
